history.content:
You need a P to pass. An NP will mean you don't get credit and can't graduate

a P is given for C- or above, NP is given for D+ or below. However, to receive credit for a class, you only need a D- (or higher). So if you take the class graded and get a D- (which could correspond to an NP), you can still graduate, but if you took it on a P/NP basis you wouldn't be able to. I'd suggest checking with an advisor to confirm what I'm saying, but I suggest taking it for a grade and then asking the prof to give you at least a D- instead of an F in the worst case. Presumably they'll be generous enough to do at least that

For context, I am a graduating senior. I am currently taking a class that will help fulfill my CS Elective graduation requirement, but this semester has been crazy, it was already a hard class to begin with, and basically I'm not sure if I'm going to pass it. 

On the site it says "All courses taken for the major must be at least 3 units and taken for a letter grade" and I know that now it counts even if you P/NP it. However, it doesn't say anything about needing to pass the class to count as a major requirement.

I just wanted to clarify with anyone who might know, if worst case I get an NP in this class which I needed to fulfill that CS elective major requirement, will I still graduate?

Thanks much in advance,

Very worried bear

For context: https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/undergrads/cs/degree-reqs-upperdiv
history.subject: Do you need to pass classes taken for major requirements to graduate?
